column10: Ensure that Amazon CloudFormation stacks have not been drifted
column14: Ensure that your AWS CloudFormation stacks are not drifted from their expected template configuration. A CloudFormation stack is considered to have drifted from its configuration if one or more of its resources have been drifted. A stack resource is considered to have drifted if its actual property values differ from the expected property values specified as stack template parameters. This includes if the property or resource has been deleted. For each resource within the stack that supports drift detection
column15: Amazon CloudFormation compares the actual configuration of the resource with its expected template configuration. Only resource properties explicitly defined in the stack template are checked for drift.

column10: Ensure to use AWS Cloudfront Content Distribution Network for secure web content delivery
column14: The Cloudfront Content Distribution Network can have a significant impact on the security of your web application content delivery process. AWS Cloudfront can accelerate and deliver your web content securely over HTTPS from all of its edge locations (CDN servers). In addition to delivering securely from the edge
column15: you can also configure Cloudfront to use HTTPS connections for origin fetches so that your content is encrypted end-to-end from the application origin to your end users. The AWS Cloudfront CDN service improves the ability of your web application to absorb and mitigate potential Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks and keep the application available for legitimate users. The CDN distribution can be also integrated with AWS WAF service - a web application firewall service made available by Amazon to protect web applications against common attacks.

column10: Ensure AWS CloudFront CDN service is in use for fast and secure web content delivery
column14: Using AWS CloudFront CDN service can have a significant impact on the performance
column16: reliability and availability of your websites/applications content delivery process. CloudFront has several advantages over other Content Delivery Network providers: is fast – using a global network of 59 edge locations
column17: CloudFront caches and delivers copies of your static content close to users with minimal latency
column18: is secure - enforces HTTPS connections between the service edge locations and your origin server and can be integrated with AWS WAF (a web application firewall service made available by Amazon to protect web applications against common attacks)
column19: is highly available – engineered for HA and built on top of Amazon’s highly reliable infrastructure
column20: easy to use - you can manage CloudFront distributions with just few clicks using the Management Console or programmatically via AWS API
column21: cost effective - you only pay the web content delivered through the CDN network (pay-as-you-go price plan) and can be easily integrated with other AWS components such as EC2

column10: Ensure default EC2 security groups are not in use in order to follow AWS security best practices
column14:
The use of default security groups can indicate a lack of intentional enforcement of the principle of least privilege. Use custom security groups to ensure you are properly minimizing privilege and accessi.
Configuring all VPC default security groups to restrict all traffic will encourage least privilege security group development and mindful placement of AWS resources into security groups which will in-turn reduce the exposure of those resources.

column18: you can easily restrict which role a IAM user can assign to an EC2 instance during the launch process in order to stop the user from trying to gain elevated (overly permissive) privileges.

column10: Ensure Termination Protection feature is enabled for EC2 instances that are not part of ASGs
column14: For EC2 instances provisioned manually
column15: once the Termination Protection feature is enabled you will not be able to terminate your EC2 instances using the AWS Management Console
column16: the AWS API or the CLI until the termination protection has been disabled. However
column17: this will not prevent your instances from getting terminated if these have set the Shutdown Behavior flag to 'Terminate' when an OS-level shutdown is performed. To make sure your instances cannot be accidentally terminated
column18: you need to set first the instance Shutdown Behavior value to 'Stop' (which sets the InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior attribute value to 'stop') then enable Termination Protection safety precaution (which sets the DisableApiTermination attribute value to true).For EC2 instances provisioned automatically via AWS Cloudformation
column19: once the Termination Protection feature is enabled you will not be able to delete the stack containing the instance until the feature has been disabled (which sets the DisableApiTermination attribute value to false) in your CloudFormation template. By default
column20: the volumes associated with the EC2 instances are deleted when these are terminated (the DeletionOnTermination attribute value is set to true). With Termination Protection feature enabled
column21: you have the guarantee that your instances cannot be terminated (permanently deleted) accidentally and make sure that your EBS data remains safe.

column10: Ensure EC2 instances are using General Purpose SSD (gp2) EBS volumes instead of Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1) volumes to optimize AWS EBS costs
column14: Ensure that your EC2 instances are using General Purpose SSD (gp2) EBS volumes instead of Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1) volumes for cost-effective storage that fits a broad range of workloads. Unless you are running mission-critical applications that need more than 10000 IOPS or 160 MiB/s of throughput per volume
column15: Cloud Conformity recommends converting your io1 EBS volumes to gp2-type volumes in order to lower the cost of your monthly AWS bill while maintaining the same I/O performance. For example
column16: if your application requirements are 100GB storage and 600 IOPS (input/output operations per second) you can save roughly $31 per month using gp2 EBS volumes instead of io1 volumes as an io1-type EBS volume with 600 IOPS and 100GB storage costs $51.50/month while a gp2 volume with 600 IOPS and 200GB storage costs only $20.00/month (as of November 2016)

column10: Ensure persistent logs are enabled for your Amazon Elastic Beanstalk environment(s)
column14: The log files generated by AWS Elastic Beanstalk are all stored within an S3 bucket configured by the service when the environment is created. Most of these log files (trail and bundle logs) are removed from the S3 bucket 15 minutes after these are created
column15: so in order to retain the logs you can configure your EB environment to publish logs to Amazon S3 automatically after these have been rotated. The retained (persistent) logs can be easily retrieved using the EB Management Console or the EB CLI. You can also configure your Elastic Beanstalk environment to stream logs to Amazon CloudWatch in real time.

column11: Ensure high availability for your ELBs by using Cross-Zone Load Balancing with multiple subnets in different AZs
column14: ELB
column15: Enabling Cross-Zone Load Balancing makes it easier to deploy and manage applications that run across multiple subnets in different Availability Zones. This would also guarantee better fault tolerance and more consistent traffic flow. If one of the availability zones registered with the ELB fails (as result of network outage or power loss)
column16: the load balancer with the Cross-Zone Load Balancing activated would act as a traffic guard
column17: stopping any request being sent to the unhealthy zone and routing it to the other zone(s).

column1: Note: no extra charges — with cross-zone load balancing implemented
column2: Amazon will not charge for data transfer between the load balancer nodes and backend instances.

column5: Ensure AWS S3 buckets enforce Server-Side Encryption (SSE)
column9: When dealing with sensitive data that is crucial to your business

column10: Ensure that your NAT gateways are deployed in at least two Availability Zones (AZs)
column14: If you have EC2 instances in multiple Availability Zones and these share one NAT gateway
column15: in the event of AZ failure the NAT gateway becomes unavailable and the resources within other Availability Zones lose internet access. To create a fault-tolerant architecture
column16: make sure that your AWS NAT gateways are deployed in at least two Availability Zones (AZs)

column10: Ensure AWS VPC Managed NAT (Network Address Translation) Gateway service is enabled for high availability (HA)
column14: AWS provides two types of NAT devices: a managed NAT gateway and a NAT instance instantiated from a public AMI. Using the AWS VPC Managed NAT Gateway service instead of an NAT instance to forward traffic for your instances available in a private subnet has multiple advantages. For example
column15: the Managed NAT Gateway provides built-in redundancy for high availability (using the multi-AZ configuration) compared to the NAT instance which use just a script to manage failover
column16: Managed NAT Gateway provides better bandwidth (traffic bursts up to 10Gbps) than the NAT instance which is limited to the bandwidth allocated for the EC2 instance type used. Lastly
column17: the Managed NAT Gateway service is using optimized software to handle NAT traffic and is fully managed by AWS compared to the NAT instance which is not optimized and requires scaling and regular maintenance such as installing software updates or patches.

column10: Ensure Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) Flow Logs feature is enabled in all applicable AWS regions
column14: Flow logs enable the investigation of incidents involving unauthorized network traffic
column15: such as an attacker exfiltrating data or pivoting to other hosts. VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. After you've created a flow log
column16: you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

column10: Ensure AWS VPNs have always two tunnels active in order to enable redundancy
column14: Using two active tunnels for your AWS VPN (IPsec) connections will ensure redundancy when one of the tunnels becomes unavailable. column14: Using AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) service can have a significant impact on the security and availability of the websites/web applications running within your AWS environment. The main benefits of using Amazon WAF are: strong protection against common web-based attacks – safeguards your web applications from SQL Injection (SQLi) attacks

column10: Ensure that logging is enabled for Amazon WAFv2 Web Access Control Lists
column14: To get detailed information about the web traffic analyzed by your Web Access Control Lists (Web ACLs) you must enable logging. The log entries include the time that Amazon WAF received the request from your AWS resource
column16: and the action for the rule that each request matched. You can also send these logs to an Amazon Kinesis Firehose delivery stream with a configured storage destination
